Byline: DECLAN FAHY

SHAMED TD GV Wright last night confessed to being a drink-driver who knocked down a woman.

The Fianna Fail deputy made a grovelling apology yesterday to his innocent victim and her family.

Father-of-three Wright, 56, said he was full of remorse after last Thursday's crash in Dublin.

He said in a statement: "When returning home from Dail Eireann, I was involved in a traffic accident which led to injury to a pedestrian.

"Subsequently, tests confirmed I exceeded the breath alcohol level.

"I wish to unreservedly apologise to the person whom I injured and her family for this serious lapse of personal responsibility on my part and wish her a complete and expeditious recovery.

"I wish also to apologise to my family and friends and those whom I represent in Dublin North.

"I have been and will continue to fully co-operate with the authorities as these matters progress."

Gardai are investigating the accident and Wright could face dangerous driving charges.

If convicted he could be jailed for six months, receive a two-year driving ban and a EUR1,200 fine.

Furious anti-drink drive campaigners called for Wright to resign immediately.

Gertie Shields, of Mothers Against Drink Driving, said: "If he is a man of honour, he must step down.

"This is shocking and disgusting behaviour and his position is now untenable.

"As an elected representative, he should be ashamed of himself."

Speaking from New York, Taoiseach Bertie Ahern said: "My primary concern is for the injured lady.

"It's now a matter for the authorities and the DPP.

"It would be improper for me to comment on a matter which may influence any final decision in relation to this case."

Justin Harmon, of the Campaign Against Dangerous and Drunk Driving, said: "We condemn the two-faced hypocrisy of Fianna Fail and Bertie Ahern.

"He called for Socialist TD Joe Higgins to go to jail in support of the bin tax, but has not done the same in this incident."

Wright's vehicle hit the woman in Dublin's Mountjoy Square last Thursday, leaving her with a leg injury.

He was returning to his detached, EUR600,000 home in The Moorings, Malahide, when the crash happened.

Wright, who was born in in the North Dublin seaside town, is married with two sons and a daughter. The backbencher was re-elected to the Dail in 1997 having lost his seat in 1989.

A former businessman, he also played Gaelic football for Dublin County and was also an international basketball coach.

Wright was not at his home or his constituency office yesterday to further discuss his shame.

Radio shows were inundated with angry callers yesterday calling for Wright to resign.

The incident is a complete embarrassment to the Government, which has vowed to clamp down on drink- driving and road offences in general.

Fianna Fail Parliamentary Party Chairman Seamus Kirk said: "On the issue of driving while intoxicated, Fianna Fail has reduced the blood alcohol limit allowed by law and increased the penalties for those convicted.

"The party believes everyone has a duty to observe the law in that regard and not endanger themselves or others by driving while over the allowable blood alcohol limit."
